Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Radiation Tolerant Low-mass Silicon Tracker for the LHCb Upgrade
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a MRI development award to the particle physics group at Syracuse University to design and build the central core of the Upgrade Tracker (the UT) for the LHCb Experiment, located at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland. LHCb is currently the premier dedicated experiment for the study of hadronic production of heavy quark systems containing charm and beauty quarks. The UT is a silicon tracking detector, and the Syracuse group has key expertise to develop and deliver this important instrumentation to the experiment, including fundamental knowledge of the underlying physics, devices, metrology, simulations, and implementation. The scientific focus of the Syracuse group is directed toward the study of B decays, Charm decays, and study of CP violation processes which are related to and potentially important for the understanding of the matter-antimatter asymmetry observed in the universe. The proposed UT will enable LHCb to study these very rare processes effectively and to fully exploit the increased luminosity planned for LHC operations at collision energies up to 14 TeV and collision intervals of 25 nsec. The broader impacts of the program are significant for the training of young research scientists in instrumentation development and will greatly enhance their training and exposure to state of the art hardware and electronics systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The LHCb experiment is one of the four experiments located at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva, SW that collides protons with protons at 13 Trillion electron volt energy. This is largest energy collider ever built. A myriad of possibilities exists for discoveries concerning the fundamental constitutents of matter and their basic interactions. The LHCb experiment concentrates on finding new particles and new forces by examining the decays of particles containing either the b quark or c quark. Quarks are fundamental constituents of matter. The b and c quarks have lifetimes that are small but large enough that the particles containing them move a visable distance. A lot can happen during that travel so the particles they decay into are influenced by whatever particles exist in nature even at large masses. So these decays give us indirect information on all the massive states in nature.

The LHCb detector shown in Fig. 1 has been taking data since late 2010. Many interesting results have been obtained. The detector performed excellently and it was noticed that the data collected per unit time could be increased by a factor between 5 and 10, depending on the specific decay of interest. Thus, a plan for an upgrade of the detector was born and approved. It involves replacing the electronics and components for most of the detector subsystems.

The Syracuse group led the effort to replace the detector denoted as TT in Fig.1. This detector consists of 4 layers of silicon strips. Using this MRI grant, and with the help of collaborators that subsequently joined the effor, we developed the overall design of the system including the mechanical support, the front-end electronic chip, the silicon detectors and the readout electronics. Specific developments at Syracuse include the developement of the "stave" concept where each layer of silion is broken in 12-14 vertical strips which support a ladder of silcion, and the readout cables. We also developed and tested the silicon detectors which included several novel features not normalized used in such devices, including a semicircular whole to fit snuggly around the beam pipe (see Fig. 1.), a novel way of feeding high voltage to the sensor and internal scheme for adapting the strip width of the silicon to that of the electronic chips.

This effort used about a dozen undergraduate students and a similar number of graduate students that helped with detector prototype and the readout electronics. Figure 2 shows three of the undegraduate students preparing materials for the construction of the first stave.

This MRI grant allowed for the successful completion of the R&D for the UT project for the Syracuse related projects. We also helped with the efforts on the front-end electronic chip, call  Salt, whose design was done by the Kracow group, testing the data cables designed by Milano and working with the Maryland group for the off-detector electronics design.
